this has been upstreamed.

> If make fails, we can't rerun the make process, because existing patches can't apply again.

Maybe just need to fix a cleanup stage for some packages?

I mean usually we have the next steps:

1. Remove a directory with source code if it exists
2. Download and unpack some files if it's required
3. Apply patches
4. Build
5. Install

Some packages like ntp have incorrect 1st step:
NTP_VERSION is 4.2.8p15+dfsg and we try to remove ntp-$(NTP_VERSION) but in fact directory is named `ntp-4.2.8p15`

So if directory with source code is removed correctly we don't have any issues with applying patches when we rerun make. But it's just a suggestion.
Probably your PR fixes another bug.

> > If make fails, we can't rerun the make process, because existing patches can't apply again.
>

I find the difference, your device got the wrong HwSKU info, Default HwSKU should be Seastone-DX010. I guess you installed the image through sonic-installer and your device had the wrong HwSKU info in config db.
Please try the following method, then check the HwSKU info and execute the 'show platform firmware updates' again.
``` bash
admin@sonic:~$ sudo rm /etc/sonic/config_db.json
admin@sonic:~$ sudo config-setup factory
admin@sonic:~$ sudo reboot
# After reboot complete:
admin@sonic:~$ show platform summary 
```
You should see the hwsku info like this:
``` bash
admin@sonic:~$ show platform summary
Platform: x86_64-cel_seastone-r0
HwSKU: Seastone-DX010
ASIC: broadcom
ASIC Count: 1
```

That's standard practice for the source package (orig.tar.\*) being the same, but the debian package (debian.tar.\*) being different, since the upstream version is the same, but Debian is making specific changes. See [here](https://tracker.debian.org/news/1370213/accepted-isc-dhcp-441-23deb11u1-source-into-stable-security/) for details on the new version.

So this is CVE security updates by Debian security team.

can you describe how much better the performance?

I did not record specific data. But this is the reason, if there is no request, you need to use curl to get data from bmc, and each query needs to start a curl process. pmon is a circular query, which will pull up multiple processes in a loop, which consumes a lot. Using request does not need to pull up the process. @lguohan
@pettershao-ragilenetworks where is this request used. can you point me that?

Used for pmon to obtain information from bmc through REST API, such as psu, fan, led, etc.
@prgeor

use request: 
![img_v2_9862d362-c049-47d9-adf7-66794e1696cg](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/81281940/210949911-1c57d575-a903-4ca0-a2be-6d9cd3ec01bb.jpg)
use curl:
![img_v2_7232eeb6-4329-494f-9408-9ec5665f706g](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/81281940/210950089-46048a2d-80da-45f6-bb30-639c83ca8de0.jpg)

In r6010 products, pmon needs to obtain information from bmc with REST API. Such as psu, fan, led and so on. Without request component, can only be obtained through curl. When the process using REST api obtain information, each query needs to start a curl process, which consumes a lot of resources. When use the request component, can reduce resource consumption.

![img_v2_6ceacf09-73fd-4588-ba94-429bd4925c1g](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/81281940/210950256-da5de1a6-b628-4c77-9b72-883cada6fe80.jpg)

Each process uses curl to get data with REST api.

comments.body: Cherry-pick PR to 202211: https://github.com/sonic-net/sonic-buildimage/pull/13639

I think current diff still has duplicate input packets issue,
Each time we call dhcp_devman_add_intf( ) will have a rx socket monitor on all interfaces, kernel will duplicate packets to all matched sockets. 

Normally, for socket listen on all interfaces, we just need one instance and give this socket a big enough rcvd buffer size.
For TX socket as it bind to particular interface, so each interface has a socket would be fine. 

And if we use one socket for all input interface binding, better to use batch process for better performance, that is one read ready event will trigger a batch of recvfrom operations.

Each dhcpmon process will only monitor one vlan
https://github.com/sonic-net/sonic-buildimage/blob/3740f1efb7be8be325e93f37834adf7cc61e169f/dockers/docker-dhcp-relay/dhcp-relay.monitors.j2#L44

I suspect libyang backlink issue. 

Take this failed test as example: `test_find_ref_paths__path_is_table__returns_ref_paths`
```
2022-12-15T07:27:30.8137237Z E         ['/ACL_TABLE/DATAACL/ports/0',
2022-12-15T07:27:30.8137717Z E          '/ACL_TABLE/EVERFLOW/ports/0',
2022-12-15T07:27:30.8138209Z E          '/ACL_TABLE/EVERFLOWV6/ports/0',
2022-12-15T07:27:30.8138709Z E          '/ACL_TABLE/EVERFLOWV6/ports/1',
2022-12-15T07:27:30.8139216Z E       -  '/ACL_TABLE/NO-NSW-PACL-V4/ports/0',
2022-12-15T07:27:30.8139561Z E       ?                                     ^
2022-12-15T07:27:30.8139812Z E       
2022-12-15T07:27:30.8140252Z E       +  '/ACL_TABLE/NO-NSW-PACL-V4/ports/0']
2022-12-15T07:27:30.8140585Z E       ?                                     ^
2022-12-15T07:27:30.8141019Z E       
2022-12-15T07:27:30.8141499Z E       -  '/VLAN_MEMBER/Vlan1000|Ethernet0',       <<=== missing VLAN_MEMBER 
2022-12-15T07:27:30.8142026Z E       -  '/VLAN_MEMBER/Vlan1000|Ethernet4',       <<=== missing VLAN_MEMBER
2022-12-15T07:27:30.8142539Z E       -  '/VLAN_MEMBER/Vlan1000|Ethernet8']       <<=== missing VLAN_MEMBER
```
After adding this YANG model, it loses VLAN_MEMBER ref path.
Though the RADIUS yang model is not related to this test, it breaks the ref pathfinding for other YANG models.

I am afraid GCU feature will be broken if we merge this PR.

I think @li-pingmao is working to upgrade libyang to libyang2. But libyang2 is missing many APIs that sonic_yang has been using. So the work is not completed yet.

FYI - this PR breaks sonic-mgmt QoS tests when run against T2 VoQ chassis, as now the BUFFER_QUEUE_TABLE has keys based on the system port for the front panel port instead of just the front panel port as before. The failure  occurs at https://github.com/sonic-net/sonic-mgmt/blob/master/tests/qos/qos_sai_base.py#L1346

With this change, a snip bit of the keys in the CONFIG database for BUFFER_QUEUE_TABLE are:
```
admin@ixre-egl-board3:~$ docker exec database0 redis-cli -n 0 keys "*BUFFER_QUEUE_TABLE*"
BUFFER_QUEUE_TABLE:ixre-egl-board3:asic1:Ethernet184:5-6
BUFFER_QUEUE_TABLE:ixre-egl-board3:asic0:Ethernet136:0-2
BUFFER_QUEUE_TABLE:ixre-egl-board4:asic0:Ethernet80:0-2
BUFFER_QUEUE_TABLE:ixre-egl-board3:asic1:Ethernet272:0-2
BUFFER_QUEUE_TABLE:ixre-egl-board4:asic0:Ethernet136:5-6
BUFFER_QUEUE_TABLE:ixre-egl-board4:asic0:Ethernet88:0-2
BUFFER_QUEUE_TABLE:ixre-egl-board4:asic1:Ethernet152:3-4
BUFFER_QUEUE_TABLE:ixre-egl-board4:asic0:Ethernet56:5-6
BUFFER_QUEUE_TABLE:ixre-egl-board3:asic0:Ethernet16:0-2
BUFFER_QUEUE_TABLE:ixre-egl-board4:asic0:Ethernet136:3-4
BUFFER_QUEUE_TABLE:ixre-egl-board4:asic1:Ethernet216:5-6
.
.
```
Is it safe to assume that the system ports would always have the format <hostname>:<asic_namespace>:<front_panel_port>
